{{distinguish2|[[currency code]] (the three-letter ISO 4217 abbreviation) or [[Currency (typography)|the Â¤ currency symbol]]}} {{SpecialChars | image = Gold Currency Symbols.svg | special = [[Unicode]] currency signs | fix = Help:Special_characters | characters = currency signs }} A '''currency sign''' is a graphic symbol used as a shorthand for a [[currency]]'s name, especially in reference to amounts of money. They typically employ the first letter or character of the currency, sometimes with minor changes such as [[Typographic ligature|ligature]]s or overlaid vertical or horizontal bars. Today, [[ISO 4217]] codes are used instead of currency signs for most official purposes,{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} though currency signs may be in common use in many other contexts. Few currencies in the world have no short-hand symbol at all. Although many former currency signs were rendered obsolete by the adoption of the [[euro]], having a new and unique currency sign â implementation of which requires the adoption of new [[unicode]] and type formats â has now become a [[status symbol]] for international currencies. The [[European Commission]] considers part of the success of the euro was the global recognition of the [[euro sign]] {{euro}}. In 2009, India launched a public competition to replace the â¨ ligature it shared with neighboring countries.Westcott, K. (2009) [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/7923825.stm India seeks rupee status symbol], [[BBC]] 10 March 2009, accessed 1 September 2009 It finalized its new currency symbol, [[Indian rupee sign|â¹]] ({{INR}}) on 15 July 2010. It is a blend of the [[Latin alphabet|Latin letter]] '[[R]]' with the [[Devanagari]] letter "'''[[à¤°]]'''." {{wide image|Currency-Symbol Regions of the World circa 2006.png|1000px|alt=via Radical Cartography.net}} ==Usage== When writing currency amounts the location of the sign varies by currency. Many currencies, especially in Latin America and the English-speaking world, place it before the amount (e.g., R$50.00); many others place it after the amount (e.g., 50.00 Sâ£); and the [[Cape Verdean escudo]], like the former [[Portuguese escudo]] and [[French franc]], placed its sign in the decimal position (i.e., 20$00).Banco de Cabo Verde. "[http://www.bcv.cv/vPT/Notas%20e%20Moedas/Moedas/Paginas/Moedas.aspx Moedas]." Accessed 25 Feb 2011. The decimal separator also follows local countries' standards. For instance, the United Kingdom often uses an [[interpunct]] as the decimal point on price stickers (e.g., Â£5Â·52), although not in print. Commas (e.g., 5,00 â¬) or decimal points (e.g., R$50.00) are common separators used in other countries. See [[Decimal separator#Dot countries|decimal separator]] for information on international standards. ==Design== {| style="float: right;" |+ |- ||[[File:Euro Construction.svg|thumb|right|Official dimensions of the [[euro sign]].]] ||[[File:Moreeurosigns.png|thumb|right|Dimensions of the sign in a selection of fonts.]] |} Older currency signs have evolved slowly, often from previous currencies. The [[dollar sign|dollar]] and [[dollar sign|peso sign]]s originated from the mark employed to denote [[Spanish dollar|the Spanish ''real de a ocho'']], whereas the [[Pound sign|pound]] and [[pound sign|lira sign]]s evolved from an [[L]] standing for ''[[Libra (weight)|libra]]'', a Roman pound of silver. Newly invented currencies and currencies adopting new signs have symbolism closer to their adopter. The added center bar in the [[euro sign]] is meant to symbolize stability{{cite web|title=The Euro. Our money.|url=http://www.ecb.int/pub/pdf/other/eurobren.pdf|publisher=ECB|accessdate=2011-05-21|page=3|format=PDF}}. The [[Indian rupee sign|new Indian rupee symbol]], {{INR}}, is a stylized combination of Latin and [[Devanagari]] letters. There are also other considerations, such as the perception of the business community{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} and how the sign is rendered on computers. For a new symbol to be used, software to render it needs to be promulgated and keyboards need to be altered or shortcuts added to type the icon.
